tonight.

Yes.

and Amplify for hosting this wonderful event.

So yeah, I came here to talk about Neovim.
Just kidding.
I have got off the past three months
of giving quite a few conference talks.
And the most recent one ended in
Alicante, Spain a few weeks ago.
I was speaking at React Alicante,
put a lot of work into that talk.
Woke up the next morning, was having coffee on my balcony.
Hadn't looked at my phone yet, just
looking at the beautiful water.
I looked down.
I have a DM from Mike.
Will you speak at the Effect meetup?
And I said, I will do it under the condition
that I do not have to write another slide deck.
Thank you, thank you.
So I didn't really know what I was going to talk about.
I have a high level goal of what I want to talk about.
I think it's quite fitting to follow a bunch of the talks
tonight.
And if anyone has seen anything I
talk about on Twitter or Twitch,
this is very much like in my wheelhouse.
I want to talk about the past,
present, and future of not only
TypeScript, but myself as a developer.
So as some context and background on me,
I am currently a software engineer at Vercel.
I've been working in TypeScript, JavaScript, Node, React,
GraphQL, all that stuff, going into my 11th year,
and writing JavaScript since I was 13, so even longer.
Despite my baby face, I am over the age of 30.
So I've been doing this quite a while.
And throughout the years of writing lots and lots
and lots of TypeScript and JavaScript and Node
and all this stuff, you run into the same problems
over and over again.
And I should say that I also did consulting
for 6 and 1 by 5 years.
And the thing with consulting is consultants
aren't hired when things are going well.
It's not rainbows and unicorns.
It's normally you're getting dropped
into a dumpster fire of a code base,
and you have to fix things up.
And throughout that time, like I was saying,
you just see the same exact problems over and over
and over again.
And as much as I have made my career off of JavaScript
and TypeScript, and I have my deepest expertise
in this language, it is also probably the most frustrating
language to work in and the
most frustrating and hard language
to ship quality, stable production software with.
I think it has the lowest barrier of entry.
Of most languages or stacks, which
is an amazing property of the language in our community.
But it also lends itself to focusing on the happy path
too easily, neglecting errors, like all the things we've
already heard tonight.
And you see this over and over and over again.
And I've had the privilege across many companies
through consulting and working at Vercel
and working at Formidable.
I've had the real lucky opportunities
to work with some of the best JS and JS devs in the world.
And even they are not immune for making these mistakes.
So that's kind of where Effect comes in.
And I think Effect really can be the answer to that.
As I had gone through my career journey prior to my job
at Vercel, which I just started at in February,
I was working at a company for just about two years
where I got hired as the lead front end
dev at this institutional DeFi company.
I'm not a crypto person, but
it was still a blast to work at.

However-- Jesus, shouldn't have sat down here.
I've been a full stack dev my entire career, genuinely.
And I plan to continue being a
full stack dev at the position.
But this company built all of their services
and a few of their other web apps
and even a Excel plugin with OCaml.
Yes.
So this is where I get functional programming pilled.
I spend the past two years diving into OCaml.
I am writing web apps that
compile with Melange to JavaScript.
I'm shipping NPM packages, not
with PureScript, but with OCaml.
I just fall in love with this language.
I had some experience with Elixir back in the day,
but nothing-- I wasn't at the point of maturity or tenure
to really understand what functional programming meant
and how it could be practical and applied.
And then once I got that opportunity to work in OCaml,
it just clicked, working with modules.
The light bulb moment when you finally
have that experience of what a good type system feels with
or feels like.
Sorry, TypeScript, but Hindley-Milner is just way better.
And I've kind of been chasing that goal
of exposing other TypeScript developers that
have had that same background, that have my background.
10 years of TypeScript and JavaScript,
and suddenly I get tossed in my
head in functional programming.
And I think functional programming can get a bad rep,
and rightly so.
It's easy to fall into this jargon of bone ad and functors
and tri-functors and all this stuff.
I don't think that's necessarily the value proposition,
which I think we can probably all agree on if you're here
writing Effect.
So how do I get to Effect?
So I started at Vercel.
I had unfortunately no longer writing OCaml full time.
Over the past year, going through my experience
learning OCaml from time to time,
I would have these guys from Effectful show up.
And my Twitter replies, hey, have you seen Effect?
Yes.
Have you heard of this?
You want to check this out?
It's like the meme of the guy in the elevator.
I don't even think about you at all.
So finally, I'm back into TypeScript world,
and Effect three comes out.
And throughout the past 10 years,
despite having worked in TypeScript,
the most reliable software I ever shipped
was one in OCaml, and second, I worked two years and go.
And the first couple of days after React 3 came out,
I saw in it a lot of the values and a lot of the properties
that I felt building reliable software that wasn't going
to cause me to wake up at 2 in the morning from pages
in Effect.
So I decided to give it a real shot.
And I was that eager junior dev, mid-level dev,
that saw things like Ramda and Fpts and all these things
and wanted to try it.
And I've made messes with RxJS.
I've cleaned up other people's messes in these libraries
through consulting for six and a half years.
So I was that person that was insanely skeptical of Effect
up front, and having taken the time
to actually build something, multiple things.
I've shipped stuff for freelance clients now.
I've shipped my own stuff with it.
I see the value.
I don't want to build without it anymore.
Yeah, so that kind of leads me to like--
it's like this--
it's not a higher-chasing, but it's like,
how do you teach that experience, that light bulb
moment that, you know, Elliot,
this slide with all the things
you love about it, the building with Legos
and the composability and just
like every single code sample
we saw tonight, it looks almost the same.
Every single person's Effect code
was readable using the same patterns.
Once you get down those three or four ways that
look unlike anything else, really, in the TypeScript
too, so if you can get that down,
you get these beautiful guide rails
that lead you to simplicity and simple abstractions that
just compose and build up.
And it really does feel like building with Legos.
So yeah, I guess the final part of this
is similar to our last speaker's last point.
It's like, how do we bridge this gap?
How do we get this light bulb moment to more people?
And that's the thing I've been chasing for two years,
getting people to try OCaml or try Gleam or try Effect.
And I think we're doing a lot of the right things, I think.
I mean, even in the past eight months, six months--
I don't even know how long it
was since Free Auto came out--
the quality of the stuff you guys have put out,
the dock improvements, I'm very confident
that if there was ever a library and ecosystem
to bridge that gap from real world functional programming
ideals to TypeScript and more broadly the entire JavaScript
ecosystem, it's going to be this project.
And I think we need more people like Elliott
who talk about their experience.
And I think we need to be real about the things
that suck and the things that are hard
and the things that are weird.
And we need to not lose sight
of when our teammates are like,
this is weird, or I don't get this.
We need to meet them where they're at,
because not everyone has had that light bulb moment
that it's easy to lose sight of or forget what it
was like before that moment.
So yeah, I want to help build with all the rest of you
to continue to help bridge that gap
and ultimately make better TypeScript software.
So thank you.
